text:
I know I’ve been missing for a while.
Life threw a double punch - COVID and typhoid - and trust me, it wasn’t easy.

A few days in the hospital, followed by weeks of slow recovery - physically, mentally, emotionally.

Sometimes, you don’t just need rest.
You need to pause.

Health issues aside, life hasn’t been easy lately.
Challenges - some expected, most not - came in waves.

And no matter how strong you are, there are moments where everything feels just… too much.

Breathe.
And be kind to yourself.

That’s exactly what I’ve been doing.
I took a break. Logged off. Focused on healing.

And now, step by step - I’m finding my way back.
Not rushing. Just rebuilding - slowly and mindfully.

To everyone who checked in: thank you.
To everyone else navigating tough times: I see you. Take your time. Healing isn’t a race.

I’m recovering.
Slowly. Gently. One day at a time.

Trying to find my rhythm again - without burning myself out.

If you’re going through something right now - whether it’s physical, mental, emotional -

Please know: it’s okay to pause.
 - It’s okay to fall behind.
 - It’s okay to not be okay.

You owe no one an explanation for choosing your peace.
I’m still in that space - of reflection, realignment, and rebuilding.

I’m coming back - one little step at a time.

Some of the smartest people I know are jobless right now.

Not because they’re lazy.
Not because they don’t have skills.
But because the system is broken.

– Companies post fake jobs.
– They reopen the same roles every month.
– Candidates solve 5-hour assignments and get ghosted.
– Referrals go nowhere.
– Rejections come in 2 minutes.
– Or never.

And yet we still say: *'Keep applying. Your time will come.'*

Maybe.
But maybe the problem isn't us.
Maybe it’s the way hiring works — with no empathy, no accountability, no respect.

If you’re tired, frustrated, burnt out — you’re not alone.
You’re not a failure. You’re just stuck in a system that was never built to be kind.

And I’m done pretending that’s normal.

Unpopular opinion:

The job market isn’t about talent anymore.
It’s about timing, luck, and how loud you can scream on LinkedIn.

Some of the smartest people I know are unemployed.
Some of the most average ones are getting promoted.

Why?
Because this game isn’t fair.
It never was.

We don’t reward loyalty.
We reward performative work.
We don’t hire for skill.
We hire who sounds skilled.

So if you're tired, bitter, or confused - you're not broken.
You're just awake.

Awake enough to realize that sometimes…
you can do everything right and still be left behind.

This post is for the ones who aren’t clapping right now -
because they’re still stuck in a loop.

You’re not invisible.
You’re just not loud yet.

No one talks about silent layoffs.

Because there's no email.
No public announcement.
No 'we’re downsizing.'

Just:

Fewer projects assigned to you

Fewer replies to your messages

Important meetings suddenly not including you

Slowly being made to feel… invisible

Until one day, you realize -
They’re not firing you.
They’re pushing you to quit.

It’s not written in any HR policy.
But it happens. Quietly. Brutally. Strategically.

You start doubting yourself.
You think maybe it’s my fault.
You start working harder—until burnout becomes your new normal.

Let me say this loud:
It was never your fault.

Companies don’t always cut costs by cutting heads.
Sometimes, they just cut your purpose.

And if this happened to you -
You didn’t 'fail.'
You survived something no one warns you about.

Let’s talk about it.
Let’s make it visible.
Because staying silent only protects the ones doing it.

The world doesn’t need more billionaires.
It needs more kind people.

Be the one who says 'thank you' -
To the delivery partner who’s drenched in rain,
Yet hands you your parcel with a smile.

Be the one who holds the door -
Even if you're running late.
Kindness doesn’t check the time.

Be the one who waves at the cleaner in your office.
They pick up after you.
And no one ever says their name.

Text your friend who’s gone quiet.
Not to ask why.
Just to say: 'I’m here. No pressure to reply.'

Compliment someone’s handwriting.
Someone’s sweater.
Someone’s presentation.
You never know how long they waited to hear something nice.

Ask your cab driver if he’s eaten.
Not out of sympathy.
Out of humanity.

Talk to the little kid in your building’s lift.
He’ll tell you how many stars are in his drawing.
And you’ll forget how heavy your day was.

Say 'I’m proud of you' to your younger sibling.
They look strong. But they still crave your validation.

Pay for the tea of the guy standing behind you in line.
No photo. No reel. No caption.
Just pay. And walk away.

Say sorry first.
Even if your ego throws a tantrum.
Love > winning.

Call your grandparents.
They don't want much -
Just your voice and five minutes of your day.

Tell your teacher from school:
'’Ma’am, I still remember what you taught me.''
It might make her whole month.

We spend so much time trying to be liked.
Try being loving.
Try being light.

Because in the end,
No one will remember your salary.
They'll remember how you made them feel.

So go be the reason someone believes
the world still has good people.

That’s real success.
That’s real impact.
That’s what truly goes viral - in hearts.

Yesterday one of my closest friends asked -

'Why do good people suffer a lot?'

The question is -

Do good people suffer more?

Yes.
Because they care more.
Because they expect less.
Because they give without calculating.
Because they believe people will treat them the same way they do.

And that’s where it hurts.

They get taken for granted.
Used.
Ignored.
And then blamed for 'not having boundaries.'

People say, 'Just be strong.'
But no one asks why they had to be strong in the first place.

Being a good person in today’s world often feels like a punishment.

You help people when they’re at their lowest.
But when you’re at your lowest?
You’ll be lucky if even one person checks in.

They keep forgiving.
Keep helping.
Keep smiling - while silently breaking inside.
Because they think being good is more important than being right.

But here's what no one tells you:

Being good doesn't mean you're weak.
It means you're strong enough to not become like the ones who hurt you.

It’s easy to become bitter.
Hard to remain kind.

So if you're someone who still chooses goodness in a world that doesn't always return it...
You are rare.
You are gold.
You are not alone.

And one day, your goodness will come back to you -
Not from the people you gave it to,
But from the universe itself.

Stay kind. Even if it hurts.

Good people don’t suffer because they’re weak.
They suffer because they keep showing up - even when the world doesn’t deserve them.

If you're one of them:
Please don’t change.
Just learn to protect your peace.
Say no without guilt.
Take breaks without explaining.
And stop setting yourself on fire to keep others warm.

Being good is not your problem.
Not knowing when to stop - is.

The world needs more people like you.

Not a movie.
Not a scene from 'Gunjan Saxena'.
This happened for real.

While the whole nation was asking -
'What’s India’s response to the terror attack?'
It wasn’t a man in uniform who stood at the front.
It was Wing Commander Vyomika Singh.

In front of flashing cameras, military maps, and the eyes of the world -
She calmly briefed the nation about Operation Sindoor:
India’s precise strikes on terror bases in PoK and Pakistan.

No panic.
No chest-thumping.
Just clarity, confidence, and class.

She’s not just a pilot.
She has clocked over 2,500 flying hours in the toughest zones -
From Siachen to Arunachal.

She’s led evacuations, missions, and now, the nation's official military briefing.

While some still debate 'Can women handle pressure?'
Vyomika Singh answered with silence.
Her uniform did the talking.
Her presence did the proving.

History will remember this moment.
Not just for the operation -
But for the woman who stood tall and led from the front.

Take a bow, ma’am.
You didn’t just strike terror camps.
You struck down stereotypes.

STOP GLORIFYING DRAMA IN THE NAME OF NEWS.

It's high time we, as citizens of India, take responsibility for the kind of news we consume.

Some news channels today have turned journalism into a circus:

Fake news for TRP.

War coverage like it's a cricket match.

Sirens, shouting, and chaos in the studio.

Misrepresenting facts that insult our armed forces and damage national interest.

And the worst part?
Every view you give them = more money from ads = more noise tomorrow.

But there is a solution.

Watch DD News.
Why?

It's the only channel directly operated by the Government of India.

It sticks to facts, official sources, and press releases.

No shouting. No sensationalism. No TRP race.

We don’t need drama. We need truth.
We don’t need shouting. We need clarity.
We don’t need fake debates. We need facts.

🇮🇳 Support real journalism.
🇮🇳 Boycott noise.
🇮🇳 Jai Hind.

The name - Sindoor is perfect!

Named after the red sindoor that graces the forehead of a married Hindu woman.

But after the Pahalgam terror attack, that sindoor turned into a streak of blood.

Because on April 22, in the Pahalgam terror attack,
that sindoor was wiped away from the foreheads of 26 women.

Their husbands were murdered - not in battle, but on a peaceful trip.

And so, India responded.

Not with words. Not with warnings. But with justice.

In just 23 minutes, India's Operation Sindoor struck at the heart of terror -

across Pakistan and PoK - where those monsters were hiding.

This wasn’t revenge.
This was a message.

This wasn’t just a military strike.

It was a tribute to the broken bangles, the fading vermilion, and the mothers who couldn’t explain to their children why papa wasn’t coming back.

Touch our people, and we’ll cross mountains, borders, and skies to bring justice.

This sindoor will not fade in fear.

It will burn in rage.

And it will stand for every woman who lost her world that day.

India doesn’t forget. India doesn’t forgive.

Touch our people, and we will rewrite maps.
Break our homes, and we will break your safehouses.

This sindoor will no longer be wiped away in tears.

It will be protected by steel, sky, and spine.

India may forgive, but it will never forget.

And when it strikes back - the world watches.

Jai Hind. Bharat Mata ki Jai.

You won’t believe what happened when I taught a chaiwala SQL.
I gave him a free YouTube playlist.
He finished it in 15 days.

Then built a dashboard for his tea stall.
Now he tracks peak hours, top-selling items, and even tips.

He doesn’t have a degree.
He has discipline.

Degrees help.
But curiosity? It changes lives.

Never underestimate the power of free resources - and the will to learn.
Never underestimate me, I can write good fictional stories.

After I wrote 'Interested' under 100+ posts today but didn't get the job.

I will keep commenting 'Interested' under every single job post.
Even if:

The job requires 20 years of experience and I'm 18.

The recruiter hasn’t replied since Independence Day

The post is from 2021

The company doesn’t exist anymore

I will still comment 'Interested.'

Why?
Because that's who I am now.
I don't apply for jobs anymore.
I manifest them…
…with one powerful word: Interested.

They ghost me? I comment.
They scam me? I comment.
They post fake roles to increase engagement?
Oh you already know I’m commenting.

By 2030, I’ll be on my deathbed whispering:
'Interested.'

Because dreams die, but LinkedIn comments live forever.

Position: Human Robot
Location: Anywhere, as long as you're always online
Salary: Emotional damage + pizza on Fridays

We are hiring!
Looking for someone who:

Has 10+ years of experience (even if you're 23)

Can work 14 hours a day but say 'I love the hustle'

Doesn’t ask for leaves, weekends, or peace

Knows every tool on earth (even the ones not invented yet)

Can attend 5 meetings simultaneously without blinking

Will smile even when given feedback like 'be less you'

Perks:

Exposure (not salary)

Free mental breakdowns

A chair

Occasional thank yous (on Slack, not in person)

Bonus if:

You say 'yes' before reading the job description

You can gaslight yourself into thinking you're happy.

To apply:
Send your soul.
Or just type 'Interested' in the comments like everyone else.

A good manager doesn’t just manage your work. 
They protect your sanity.

They guide you, support you, and get the best out of you - without making you feel like trash.

But a bad manager? 
They make you question your worth every single day.

According to a *Gallup study*, 70% of the variance in team engagement is directly linked to the *manager*. 

Another survey shows *65% of employees would take a new boss over a pay raise*.

People don’t leave jobs. 
They leave toxic managers. 
And no amount of free coffee or flexible hours can fix that.

If you're a manager, ask yourself honestly: 
*Would *you* want to report to you?*

There are some influencers who'll shamelessly post all day about Crosscoder, Hey poach all day and I even saw some of them posting yesterday and today.

I have been asked to promote many times, getting 4k-5k for posting a copy-pasted post, I do colab with teams that I find useful and can be great for people.

But

Have you noticed many of them being silent on what happened in Kashmir? Some of them posted about it but the majority haven't.

You know why?

Because speaking up doesn’t pay.

There’s no brand deal. No affiliate code. No likes from corporate recruiters. No “collaboration opportunity.”

Just a simple truth: If it's not profitable, it’s not worth talking about.

Influencing has become a business, not a responsibility. And when real issues happen -issues that affect people, that deserve voices they go quiet.

Because silence is safer.

Because this issue won’t get them engagement - it could cost them everything.

– They might lose followers
– Upset brands
– Offend recruiters
– Be labelled “controversial”
– Lose out on collabs and visibility

This post might not get me likes or money. But if even one person starts questioning the silence of people they follow, it’s worth it.

And if the people with thousands of followers, with platforms, with reach… choose not to speak - then what are they even influencing?

Being an influencer doesn’t mean being brand-friendly.

It means having the guts to stand up, even when it’s uncomfortable.

Even when it hurts your reach, followers. Even when it affects your paycheck.

Use your voice for more than brand deals.

Or stop calling yourself an influencer.

So the next time you see someone flexing their 'personal brand' and hashtag#InfluencerLife, ask them one question:

What do you stand for when no one’s watching?
